member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Base.BaseFeature
member.summary:
Base node services, these are the services a node has to have. The ConnectionManager feature is also part of the base but may go in a feature of its own. The base features are the minimal components required to connect to peers and maintain the best chain.
The base node services for a node are:
the ConcurrentChain to keep track of the best chain,
the ConnectionManager to connect with the network,
DatetimeProvider and Cancellation,
CancellationProvider and Cancellation,
DataFolder,
ChainState.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Base.InvalidBlockHashStore
member.summary: In memory store of invalid block header hashes.
member.remarks:
The store has a limited capacity. When a new block header hash is marked as invalid once the capacity is reached, the oldest entry is removed and no longer considered invalid.
Entries with specified expiration time are either removed just like other entries - i.e. during an add operation when a capacity is reached, or they are removed when they are touched and it is detected that their expiration time is no longer in the future.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Base.TimeSyncBehaviorState
member.summary: State of time synchronization feature that stores collected data samples and calculates adjustments to system time.
member.remarks:
Bitcoin introduced so called adjusted time, which is implemented as a time offset added to node's system time. The offset is result of time syncing feature with network peers that collects samples from "version" network message from anyone who connects with our node (in any direction). The median of the collected samples is used as the final time offset the node uses to calculate the adjusted time.
The actual source of adjusted time is . It is the logic behind its calculation and collection of samples that resides in this class. This class modifies the date time provider using its interface every time a new time offset sample that affects the final offset is collected.
Bitcoin allowed up to 70 minutes of time adjustment to be made using this mechanism. However, Bitcoin also allowed the blocks to be mined with timestamps that are off by up to 2 hours. This is very unlike Stratis' POS, which uses very narrow windows for block timestamps. This is why we implemented our mechanism of time syncing with peers and adjusted time calculation slightly differently.
We also collect samples from network "version" messages and calculate time difference for every peer. We DO distinguish between inbound and outbound connections, however. We consider inbound connections as less reliable sources of information and we introduce to reflect that. We keep outbound time offset samples separated from inbound samples. Our final offset is also a median of collected samples, but outbound samples have much greater weight in the median calculation as per the given weight, which is dynamically adjusted depending on the inbound outbound ratio in order to protect us from all inbound and an accepted percentage of outbound.
Bitcoin's implementation only allows certain number of samples to be collected and once the limit is reached, no more samples are allowed. We do not replicate this behavior and we implement circular array to store the time offset samples. This means that once the limit is reached, we replace oldest samples with the new ones.
Finally, as the POS chain is much more sensitive to correct time settings, our user alerting mechanism is triggered much earlier (for much lower time difference) than the one in Bitcoin.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Base.TimeSyncBehaviorState.RecalculateTimeOffsetLocked
member.summary: Calculates a new value for based on existing samples.
member.remarks:
The caller of this method is responsible for holding .
The function takes a single copy of each inbound sample and combines them with a dynamic number of copies of the outbound samples in order to maintain the .
When there are many more inbound samples than outbound, which could be the case in a malicious attack, the security is still maintained by using a dynamic inbound/outbound ratio multiplier ratio on the outbound samples that maintains the accepted level of security.
We require to have at least outbound samples to change the value of .

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.BlockPulling.IBlockPuller
member.summary: Thread-safe block puller which allows downloading blocks from all chains that the node is aware of.
member.remarks:
It implements relative quality scoring for peers that are used for delivering requested blocks.
If peer that was assigned an important download fails to deliver in maximum allowed time, all his assignments will be reassigned. Reassigned downloads are processed with high priority comparing to regular requests. Blocks that are close to the node's consensus tip or behind it are considered to be important.
Maximum amount of blocks that can be simultaneously downloaded depends on total speed of all peers that are capable of delivering blocks.
We never wait for the same block to be delivered from more than 1 peer at once, so in case peer was removed from the assignment and delivered after that we will discard delivered block from this peer.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.BlockPulling.IBlockPuller.RequestPeerServices(Stratis.Bitcoin.P2P.Protocol.Payloads.NetworkPeerServices)
member.summary: Adds required services to list of services that are required from all peers.
member.remarks: In case some of the peers that we are already requesting block from don't support new service requirements those peers will be released from their assignments.

member.summary: Removes assignments for the block which has been delivered by the peer assigned to it and calls the callback.
member.remarks: This method is called for all blocks that were delivered. It is possible that block that wasn't requested from that peer or from any peer at all is delivered, in that case the block will be ignored. It is possible that block was reassigned from a peer who delivered it later, in that case it will be ignored from this peer.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Builder.Feature.FullNodeFeature
member.summary:
A feature is used to extend functionality into the full node. It can manage its life time or use the full node disposable resources.
If a feature adds an option of a certain functionality to be available to be used by the node (it may be disabled/enabled by the configuration) the naming convention is Add[Feature](). Conversely, when a feature is inclined to be used if included, the naming convention should be Use[Feature]().

member.name: P:Stratis.Bitcoin.Configuration.NodeSettings.DataDirRoot
member.summary: The path to the root data directory, which holds all node data on the machine. This includes separate subfolders for different nodes that run on the machine: a Stratis folder for a Stratis node, a Bitcoin folder for a Bitcoin node, and folders for any sidechain nodes. This value is read-only and can only be set via the NodeSettings constructor's arguments.

member.summary: The path to the Full Node's configuration file. This value is read-only and can only be set via the NodeSettings constructor's arguments.

member.name: P:Stratis.Bitcoin.Configuration.NodeSettings.ConfigReader
member.summary: A combination of the settings from the Full Node's configuration file and the command line arguments supplied to the Full Node when it was run. This places the settings from both sources into a single object, which is referenced at runtime.

member.name: P:Stratis.Bitcoin.Configuration.NodeSettings.ProtocolVersion
member.summary: The version of the protocol supported by the Full Node.

member.name: P:Stratis.Bitcoin.Configuration.NodeSettings.MinProtocolVersion
member.summary: The lowest version of the protocol which the Full Node supports.

member.name: P:Stratis.Bitcoin.Configuration.NodeSettings.Agent
member.summary: A string that is used to help identify the Full Node when it connects to other peers on a network. Defaults to "StratisNode".

member.name: P:Stratis.Bitcoin.Configuration.NodeSettings.MinTxFeeRate
member.summary: The minimum fee for a kB of transactions on the node.

member.name: P:Stratis.Bitcoin.Configuration.NodeSettings.FallbackTxFeeRate
member.summary: The default fee for a kB of transactions on the node. This value is used if no fee is specified for a transaction.

member.name: P:Stratis.Bitcoin.Configuration.NodeSettings.MinRelayTxFeeRate
member.summary: The minimum relay transaction fee for a kB of transactions on the node. A miner may not be prepared to mine a transaction for a specified fee but might be prepared to forward the transaction to another miner who will. In this situation, the transaction is propagated to other peers if the relay fee is met. For this reason, the minimum relay transaction fee is usually lower than the minimum fee.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Configuration.NodeSettings.#ctor(NBitcoin.Network,NBitcoin.Protocol.ProtocolVersion,System.String,System.String[],NBitcoin.NetworksSelector)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object.
member.param: The network the node runs on - regtest/testnet/mainnet.
Supported protocol version for which to create the configuration.
The nodes user agent that will be shared with peers.
The command-line arguments.
A selector class that delayed load a network for either - regtest/testnet/mainnet.
member.exception: Thrown in case of any problems with the configuration file or command line arguments.
member.remarks: Processing depends on whether a configuration file is passed via the command line. There are two main scenarios here: - The configuration file is passed via the command line. In this case we need to read it earlier so that it can provide defaults for "testnet" and "regtest". - Alternatively, if the file name is not supplied then a network-specific file name would be determined. In this case we first need to determine the network.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Consensus.IChainedHeaderTree
member.summary: Tree of chained block headers that are being claimed by the connected peers and the node itself. It represents all chains we potentially can sync with.
member.remarks:
This component is an extension of and is strongly linked to its functionality, it should never be called outside of CM.
View of the chains that are presented by connected peers might be incomplete because we always receive only a chunk of headers claimed by the peer in each message.
It is a role of the to decide which of the presented chains is going to be treated as our best chain. only advises which chains it might be interesting to download.
This class is not thread safe and it the role of the component that uses this class to prevent race conditions.

member.summary: Total size of unconsumed blocks data in bytes. It represents amount of memory which is occupied by block data that is waiting to be processed.
member.remarks: This value is increased every time a new block is downloaded. It's decreased when block header is being disconnected or when consensus tip is changed.

member.summary: Total amount of unconsumed blocks.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Consensus.IChainedHeaderTree.PartialValidationSucceeded(NBitcoin.ChainedHeader,System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Handles situation when partial validation for block data for a given was successful.
member.remarks:
In case partial validation was successful we want to partially validate all the next blocks for which we have block data for.
If block that was just partially validated has more cumulative chainwork than our consensus tip we want to switch our consensus tip to this block.
member.param: The chained header.
true in case we want to switch our consensus tip to .
member.returns: List of chained header blocks with block data that should be partially validated next. Or null if none should be validated.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Consensus.IChainedHeaderTree.ConnectNewHeaders(System.Int32,System.Collections.Generic.List{NBitcoin.BlockHeader})
member.summary: A new list of headers are presented by a peer, the headers will try to be connected to the tree. Blocks associated with headers that are interesting (i.e. represent a chain with greater chainwork than our consensus tip) will be requested for download.
member.remarks: The headers are assumed to be in consecutive order.
member.param: Id of a peer that presented the headers.
The list of headers to connect to the tree.
member.returns: Information about which blocks need to be downloaded together with information about which input headers were processed. Only headers that we can validate will be processed. The rest of the headers will be submitted later again for processing.
member.exception: Thrown when first presented header can't be connected to any known chain in the tree.
Thrown if checkpointed header doesn't match the checkpoint hash.
Thrown if header validation failed.
Thrown in case maximum reorganization rule is violated.

member.name: F:Stratis.Bitcoin.Consensus.ChainedHeaderTree.peerIdsByTipHash
member.summary: Lists of peer identifiers mapped by hashes of the block headers that are considered to be their tips.
member.remarks:
During the consensus tip changing process, which includes both the reorganization and advancement on the same chain, it happens that there are two entries for . This means that two different blocks are being claimed by our node as its tip. This is necessary in order to protect the new consensus tip candidate from being removed in case peers that were claiming it disconnect during the consensus tip changing process.
All the leafs of the tree have to be tips of chains presented by peers, which means that hashes of the leaf block headers have to be keys with non-empty values in this dictionary.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Consensus.ChainedHeaderTree.CreateNewHeaders(System.Collections.Generic.List{NBitcoin.BlockHeader},System.Boolean@)
member.summary: Find the headers that are not part of the tree and try to connect them to an existing chain by creating new chained headers and linking them to their previous headers.
member.remarks:
Header validation is performed on each header. It will check if the first header violates maximum reorganization rule.
When headers are connected the next pointers of their previous headers are updated.
member.param: The new headers that should be connected to a chain.
true if there wasn't enough data to validate even the first header of all presented.
member.returns: A list of newly created chained headers or null if no new headers were found.
member.exception: Thrown in case maximum reorganization rule is violated.
Thrown if it wasn't possible to connect the first new header.
Thrown if header validation failed.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Consensus.Checkpoints
member.summary: Checkpoints is a mechanism on how to avoid validation of historic blocks for which there already is a consensus on the network. This allows speeding up IBD, especially on POS networks.
member.remarks: From https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/b1973d6181eacfaaf45effb67e0c449ea3a436b8/src/chainparams.cpp#L66 : What makes a good checkpoint block? It is surrounded by blocks with reasonable timestamps (no blocks before with a timestamp after, none after with timestamp before). It also contains no strange transactions.

member.summary: Processes "getheaders" message received from the peer.
member.param: Peer from which the message was received.
Payload of "getheaders" message to process.
member.remarks:
"getheaders" message is sent by the peer in response to "headers" message until an empty array is received.
This payload notifies peers of our current best validated height, which is held by consensus tip.
If the peer is behind/equal to our best height an empty array is sent back.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Consensus.ConsensusManagerBehavior.ProcessHeadersAsync(Stratis.Bitcoin.P2P.Peer.INetworkPeer,System.Collections.Generic.List{NBitcoin.BlockHeader})
member.summary: Processes "headers" message received from the peer.
member.param: Peer from which the message was received.
List of headers to process.
member.remarks:
"headers" message is sent in response to "getheaders" message or it is solicited by the peer when a new block is validated (unless in IBD).
When we receive "headers" message from the peer, we can adjust our knowledge of the peer's view of the chain. We update its pending tip, which represents the tip of the best chain we think the peer has.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Consensus.ConsensusManagerBehavior.ProcessInvAsync(Stratis.Bitcoin.P2P.Peer.INetworkPeer,System.Collections.Generic.List{Stratis.Bitcoin.P2P.Protocol.InventoryVector})
member.summary: Processes "inv" message received from the peer.
member.param: Peer from which the message was received.
List of inventory vectors to process.
member.remarks: The "inv" message is sent unsolicited by legacy nodes to announce new blocks. It may contain non-block hashes which should be ignored. We then need to obtain the headers of the announced blocks so that the header processing can be performed as normal. We do not request the block directly as the peer may be attempting a DoS attack by spamming fake inv messages.

members.member:
Gets the block header of the block identified by the hash. API implementation of RPC call.
The block hash. True to return Json formatted block header. Json formatted . null if block not found. Returns formatted error if fails. Thrown if isJsonFormat = false" Thrown if hash is empty. Thrown if logger is not provided. Binary serialization is not supported with this method.

member.summary: Provider of the last finalized block's height and hash.

Finalized block height is the height of the last block that can't be reorged. Blocks with height greater than finalized height can be reorged.
Finalized block height value is always 0 for blockchains without max reorg property.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.P2P.Peer.INetworkPeer
member.summary:
Represents a counterparty of the node on the network. This is usually another node, but it can be a wallet, an analytical robot, or any other network client or server that understands the protocol.
The network peer is connected either inbound, if it was the counterparty that established the connection to our node's listener, or outbound, if our node was the one connecting to a remote server.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.P2P.Peer.INetworkPeer.VersionHandshakeAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Exchanges "version" and "verack" messages with the peer.
Both parties have to send their "version" messages to the other party as well as to acknowledge that they are happy with the other party's "version" information.

member.exception: Thrown when the peer rejected our "version" message.
Thrown during the shutdown or when the peer disconnects.

Both parties have to send their "version" messages to the other party as well as to acknowledge that they are happy with the other party's "version" information.
member.param: Protocol requirement for network peers the node wants to be connected to.
Cancellation that allows aborting the operation at any stage.
member.exception: Thrown when the peer rejected our "version" message.
Thrown during the shutdown or when the peer disconnects.

It is safe to try to disconnect or dispose this object multiple times, only the first call will be processed.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.P2P.Peer.NetworkPeerDisposer
member.summary: Maintains a list of connected peers and ensures their proper disposal.
member.remarks:
Each component that creates instances of should be responsible for disposing it.
Implementing this functionality in such components will lead to having similar code in these components. Instead, this class could be used in order to provide such functionality. This means that the responsibility for destroying the peer can delegated to this class, which simplifies the code of the owning component.
When a new peer is created (and the callback is used as an in the constructor) by a component that utilizes this class, should be used to inform this class about it. Once the peer is added, the owning component no longer needs to care about this peer's disposal. When a peer disconnects, this class will invoke peer's disposal in a separated task. Also when is called, all connected peers added to this component will be disposed.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.P2P.IPeerSelector.Attempted
member.summary:
Return peers which have had connection attempts, but none successful.
The result filters out peers which satisfies the above condition within the last 60 seconds and that has had more than 10 failed attempts.

member.summary:
Return peers which have had successful connection attempts.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.P2P.IPeerSelector.Fresh
member.summary: Return peers which have never had connection attempts.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.P2P.IPeerSelector.Handshaked
member.summary:

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.AsyncLock
member.summary:
An async synchronization primitive that allows the caller to await inside the critical section.
The lock is disposable, which allows the caller to use the convenient using statement and avoid caring about releasing the lock.
member.remarks: Based on https://www.hanselman.com/blog/ComparingTwoTechniquesInNETAsynchronousCoordinationPrimitives.aspx .

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.AsyncLock.Releaser
member.summary: Disposable mechanism that is attached to the parent lock and releases it when it is disposed. This allows the user of the lock to use the convenient using statement and avoid caring about manual releasing of the lock.

member.summary: Parent lock to be released when this releaser is disposed, or null if no action should be taken on disposing it.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.AsyncLock.Releaser.#ctor(Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.AsyncLock)
member.summary: Connects the releaser with its parent lock.

member.name: F:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.AsyncLock.semaphore
member.summary: Internal synchronization primitive used as a mutex to only allow one thread to occupy the critical section.

member.name: F:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.AsyncLock.releaser
member.summary:
Helper object that allows implementation of disposable lock for convenient use with using statement.
This releaser is used when the lock has been acquired and disposing it will release the lock.
member.remarks: We use the disposable interfaced in a task here to avoid allocations on acquiring the lock when it is free.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.AsyncLoop
member.summary:
Allows running application defined in a loop with specific timing.
It is possible to specify a startup delay, which will cause the first execution of the task to be delayed. It is also possible to specify a delay between two executions of the task. And finally, it is possible to make the task run only once. Running the task for other than one or infinite number of times is not supported.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.IAsyncLoopFactory.RunUntil(System.String,System.Threading.CancellationToken,System.Func{System.Boolean},System.Action,System.Action{System.Exception},System.TimeSpan)
member.summary:
Waits until a condition is met, then executes the action and completes.
Waiting is implemented using the async loop for which the task is defined as execution of the condition method followed by execution of the action if the condition is satisfied - i.e. returns true. If the condition is not satisfied, the loop waits as per setting and then it can be attempted again.
member.param: Name of the loop.
Cancellation token that triggers when the task and the loop should be cancelled.
Condition to be tested.
Method to execute once the condition is met.
Method to execute if an exception occurs during evaluation of the condition or during execution of the .
Interval between each execution of the task. If this is , the task is only run once and there is no loop. If this is null, the task is repeated every 1 second by default.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.AsyncQueue`1
member.summary:
Async queue is a thread-safe queue that can operate in callback mode or blocking dequeue mode. In callback mode it asynchronously executes a user-defined callback when a new item is added to the queue. In blocking dequeue mode, is used to wait for and dequeue an item from the queue once it becomes available.
In callback mode, the queue guarantees that the user-defined callback is executed only once at the time. If another item is added to the queue, the callback is called again after the current execution is finished.
member.typeparam: Type of items to be inserted in the queue.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.AsyncQueue`1.AsyncContext
member.summary: Execution context holding information about the current status of the execution in order to recognize if was called within the callback method.

member.name: P:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.AsyncQueue`1.AsyncContext.DisposeRequested
member.summary: Set to true if was called from within the callback routine, set to false otherwise.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.AsyncQueue`1.OnEnqueueAsync
member.summary: Represents a callback method to be executed when a new item is added to the queue.
member.param: Newly added item.
Cancellation token that the callback method should use for its async operations to avoid blocking the queue during shutdown.
member.remarks: It is allowed to call from the callback method.

If the function returns true, this is filled with the oldest item that was replaced.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.Extensions.CommandLineArgsExtensions.GetValueOf(System.String[],System.String)
member.summary:
Obtains a value of command line argument.
It is expected that arguments are written on command line as argName=argValue, where argName usually (but does not need to) starts with "-".
The argValue can be wrapped with '"' quotes from both sides, in which case the quotes are removed, but it is not allowed for argValue to contain '"' inside the actual value.
member.param: Application command line arguments.
Name of the command line argument which value should be obtained.
member.returns: Value of the specified argument or null if no such argument is found among the given list of arguments.

member.summary: Match the IP address only (the port is ignored).

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.Extensions.IPExtensions.ToIPEndPoint(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Converts a string to an IP endpoint.
member.param: String to convert.
Port to use if does not specify it.
member.returns: IP end point representation of the string.
member.remarks: IP addresses can have a port specified such that the format of is as such: address:port. IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are supported. In the case where the default port is passed and the IP address has a port specified in it, the IP address's port will take precedence. Examples of addresses that are supported are: - 15.61.23.23 - 15.61.23.23:1500 - [1233:3432:2434:2343:3234:2345:6546:4534] - [1233:3432:2434:2343:3234:2345:6546:4534]:8333 - ::ffff:192.168.4.1 - ::ffff:192.168.4.1:80 - google.com (Resolves domain name to IP Address) - google.com:80 ('') - 1233:3432:2434:2343:3234:2345:6546:4534
member.exception: Thrown in case of the port number is out of range.
Thrown in case of ipAddress or port number is invalid.
Thrown if the ipAddress is not a valid host name.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.Extensions.IPExtensions.CanBeMappedTo(System.Net.IPEndPoint,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Net.IPEndPoint},System.Net.IPEndPoint@)
member.summary: This method will try to map an white-bind endpoint to a list of already bound endpoints.
member.remarks: The method will try to compare a local endpoint to the port of the white-bind endpoint, and if found will return the local endpoint that matches. Otherwise try to compare by a match of the entire endpoint.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.SchedulerLock
member.summary:
An async reader writer lock for concurrent and exclusive work.
The class uses ConcurrentExclusiveSchedulerPair to access two task schedulers - concurrent scheduler and exclusive scheduler. The exclusive scheduler guarantees only one task to be run at the same, which is what is used as a writer lock. The concurrent scheduler allows multiple tasks to run simultaneously, but the exclusivity of exclusive scheduler is respected, so it is used as a reader lock.
member.remarks:
From the TaskFactory.StartNew() remarks: Calling StartNew is functionally equivalent to creating a Task using one of its constructors and then calling Start to schedule it for execution. However, unless creation and scheduling must be separated, StartNew is the recommended approach for both simplicity and performance.
WARNING: One has to be very careful using this class as the exclusivity of the exclusive scheduler only guarantees to actually run one task at the time, but if the task awaits, it is not considered as running and another task can be scheduled and run instead within the context of the exclusive scheduler. This means that the tasks run within both exclusive and concurrent schedulers must not await, otherwise there is a risk of a race condition. Thus in order to use this locking mechanism, one needs to first break up the asynchronous code to synchronous pieces and only then schedule the synchronous parts.

member.name: F:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.SchedulerLock.concurrentFactory
member.summary: Task factory that runs tasks using the concurrent scheduler. Serves as a reader lock.

member.name: F:Stratis.Bitcoin.Utilities.SchedulerLock.exclusiveFactory
member.summary: Task factory that runs tasks using the exclusive scheduler. Serves as a writer lock.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object with ability to cancel locked tasks.
member.param: Cancellation source to allow cancel the tasks run by the schedulers.
Number of exclusive tasks to process before checking concurrent tasks.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.Controllers.LegacyExtPubKeyConverter
member.summary: Stratis X has a version prefix starting xq5h. Full node has a version prefix xpub for extended public key. 3rd parties like Ledger haven't update yet to the full node version prefix. This class provides a way to convert from the legacy format to the current format.
member.remarks: This class can be removed when the 3rd parties update their software.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.Controllers.LegacyExtPubKeyConverter.ConvertIfInLegacyStratisFormat(System.String,NBitcoin.Network)
member.summary: Converts a legacy Stratis format into a current Stratis format Base58 extended public key.
member.param: The extended public key that may or may not need converting.
The network to get the version bytes for.
member.returns: The same extended public key if version bytes is already the Stratis full node one, or the corrected extended public key if the version bytes was the Stratis X one.

member.name: T:Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.Helpers.SentTransactionItemModelComparer
member.summary: Used for comparing a list of TransactionItemModel to each other.
member.remarks: This specific comparer has been made to filter out duplicate payment listings in the case of a transaction with multiple inputs. This causes multiple items inside the wallet data that all have the same amount, transaction/spending id and payment details. However not all fields on this model are equal to each other so we only compare the ones we need. See: https://github.com/stratisproject/Breeze/issues/175

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.Helpers.SentTransactionItemModelComparer.Equals(Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.Models.TransactionItemModel,Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.Models.TransactionItemModel)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified objects are equal.
member.param: The first object of type TransactionItemModel to compare.
The second object of type TransactionItemModel to compare.
member.returns: true if the specified objects are equal; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Returns a hash code for the specified object.
member.param: The System.Object for which a hash code is to be returned.
member.returns: A hash code for the specified object.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.Interfaces.IWalletTransactionHandler.FundTransaction(Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.TransactionBuildContext,NBitcoin.Transaction)
member.summary: Adds inputs to a transaction until it has enough in value to meet its out value.
member.param: The context associated with the current transaction being built.
The transaction that will have more inputs added to it.
member.remarks: This will not modify existing inputs, and will add at most one change output to the outputs. No existing outputs will be modified unless is specified. Note that inputs which were signed may need to be resigned after completion since in/outputs have been added. The inputs added may be signed depending on whether a is passed. Note that all existing inputs must have their previous output transaction be in the wallet.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.Interfaces.IWalletTransactionHandler.GetMaximumSpendableAmount(Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.WalletAccountReference,Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.FeeType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Calculates the maximum amount a user can spend in a single transaction, taking into account the fees required.
member.param: The account from which to calculate the amount.
The type of fee used to calculate the maximum amount the user can spend. The higher the fee, the smaller this amount will be.
true to include unconfirmed transactions in the calculation, false otherwise.
member.returns: The maximum amount the user can spend in a single transaction, along with the fee required.

member.name: M:Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.Wallet.AddNewAccount(System.String,Stratis.Bitcoin.Features.Wallet.CoinType,System.DateTimeOffset,System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.String)
member.summary: Adds an account to the current wallet.
member.remarks: The name given to the account is of the form "account (i)" by default, where (i) is an incremental index starting at 0. According to BIP44, an account at index (i) can only be created when the account at index (i - 1) contains at least one transaction.
member.param: The password used to decrypt the wallet's .
The type of coin this account is for.
Creation time of the account to be created.
The index at which an account will be created. If left null, a new account will be created after the last used one.
The name of the account to be created. If left null, an account will be created according to the .
member.returns: A new HD account.

member.param: The type of coin this account is for.
The extended public key for the wallet.
Zero-based index of the account to add.
Creation time of the account to be created.
member.returns: A new HD account.

member.summary: Adds an account to the current account root using encrypted seed and password.
member.remarks: The name given to the account is of the form "account (i)" by default, where (i) is an incremental index starting at 0. According to BIP44, an account at index (i) can only be created when the account at index (i - 1) contains transactions.
member.param: The password used to decrypt the wallet's encrypted seed.
The encrypted private key for this wallet.
The chain code for this wallet.
The network for which this account will be created.
Creation time of the account to be created.
The index at which an account will be created. If left null, a new account will be created after the last used one.
The name of the account to be created. If left null, an account will be created according to the .
member.returns: A new HD account.

member.summary: Creates a number of additional addresses in the current account.
member.remarks: The name given to the account is of the form "account (i)" by default, where (i) is an incremental index starting at 0. According to BIP44, an account at index (i) can only be created when the account at index (i - 1) contains at least one transaction.

The number of addresses to create.
Whether the addresses added are change (internal) addresses or receiving (external) addresses.
member.returns: The created addresses.

member.summary: Lists all spendable transactions in the current account.
member.param: The current height of the chain. Used for calculating the number of confirmations a transaction has.
The network this account holds transactions for.
The minimum number of confirmations required for transactions to be considered.
member.returns: A collection of spendable outputs that belong to the given account.
member.remarks: Note that coinbase and coinstake transaction outputs also have to mature with a sufficient number of confirmations before they are considered spendable. This is independent of the confirmations parameter.
